Dear Susan Joy Mitchell:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (517) 899-6024.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Visitation and family time; in person contact
Title
1

Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12421
Section (1) An agency shall develop a plan of visitation and family
Description time for each child in foster care consistent with the child's
service plans, as required by R 400.12419 and R
400.12420 to ensure the safety and well-being of the child.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Foster Care Worker 1 was court ordered to have video visits with
Dad while he was in jail and did not follow through. Other
parenting visits were cancelled and not made up/rescheduled.
Investigation Document Review:
A review of the social work contact information in MiSACWIS
indicated the virtual parenting visits with Youth A and her father
were not able to be completed due to technical difficulties
associated with the system utilized by the jail. The record
indicated the foster care worker did make reasonable efforts for
the visits to occur, but the father was released before the problem
was resolved.
The social work contacts further indicated ongoing contact on the
part of the foster care worker with the father to eventually
establish an acceptable plan to accommodate him. The fathers
parenting visitation plan developed was for 1 time a week for 2
hours instead of 2 times a week for 1 hour each.
The social work contacts indicated there were times when the
normally scheduled parenting visits with Youth A and her mother
were not able to be completed for varying reasons. The
documentation indicated the time was subsequently allowed to be
made up in future scheduled visits. The record indicated the
mother of Youth A requested having parenting visits once a week
for 2 hours instead of twice a week for 1 hour each. This
requested schedule was subsequently implemented.
Interviews:
The Complainant 1 was contacted by telephone on 2/1/2024 for
any additional information. A message was left for the foster
parent to contact this consultant with any collaborative
information. The foster parent did not provide any additional
information.
I interviewed the Foster Care Supervisor 1 by telephone on
4/17/2024. Foster Care Supervisor 1 stated documentation of the
foster home visits were in the information system for review.
2

Foster Care Supervisor 1 stated she reviews case information with
the workers on at least a weekly basis and would be aware if a
worker had not completed the required monthly foster home visits.
Foster Care Supervisor 1 stated she completed the December
2023 foster home visit with the new case manager as a
supervision and training opportunity for the new foster care
worker. The description of the circumstances reported by Foster
Care Supervisor 1 was consistent with the social work contact
entries in the foster child case record.
Staff 1 was the foster care worker during the time associated with
this investigation. Staff 1 was interviewed by telephone on
5/1/2024. Staff 1 confirmed there was a problem with parenting
time during Parent 1’s incarceration.
I interviewed Foster Mom 1 by telephone on 4/24/2024. Foster
Mom 1 stated things were currently progressing and at a court
hearing on 4/24/2024 the parents were granted unsupervised
visitation. Foster Mom 1 stated she thought things improved when
a new case worker was assigned in December 2023.
I interviewed Parent 1 by telephone on 5/1/2024. Parent 1
confirmed he was not able to have parenting time during his
temporary incarceration due to problems with the system used by
the jail. Parent 1 reported he has been satisfied with parenting
time being provided since his release. Parent 1 stated he has
recently been authorized by the court to have unsupervised
parenting time.
Analysis The findings of this investigation determined the foster care
worker was able to develop a parent visitation plan cooperatively
with the parents of Youth A that was acceptable for them. Social
work contacts documented in the case record demonstrated
attempts by the foster care worker to complete video parenting
contacts with the father while he was temporarily incarcerated.
Technical issues associated with the system outside the foster
care workers control were not resolved before the father was
released.
Reasonable efforts were made to provide parenting time for
Parent 1 as determined/confirmed during the interview with Parent
1. Parent 1 confirmed satisfaction with the scheduling of parenting
time for Parent 1.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
3

Rule Code Visitation and family time; in person contact
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12421
Section (2) An agency social service worker shall visit the foster
Description child, and the foster parent, if applicable, in the child's
placement at least once every month.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Foster Care Worker 1 did not visit the foster home for any home
visits for the entire time she was on the case (October-December).
Investigation Documents Reviewed:
The social work contact record documented foster home visits by
the foster care worker were completed 10/23/2023, 11/10/2023,
12/22/2023, 1/29/2024, and 2/26/2024.
The summary of the narrative for the 10/23/2023 visit is that a
home visit occurred between Youth A, Foster Mom 1, and Staff 1.
Youth A was safe and the environment was appropriate. Foster
Mom 1 reported no further concerns or needs regarding Youth A
or themselves.
The summary of the narrative for the 11/10/2023 visit is that Staff
1 picked Youth A up at her foster home for her parenting time.
Staff 1 provided Foster Mom 1 with the consent to treat cards in
case of emergencies. Youth A showed Staff 1 Youth A’s bedroom
she shared with her older sister. The bedroom was safe and
appropriate. Youth A is continuing to do well at her foster home
and there are no current concerns for Youth A from her foster
parents.
The summary of the narrative for the 12/22/2023 visit is Foster
Care Supervisor 1 and Staff 2 met Youth A in Youth A’s foster
home with both foster parents present. Concerns regarding
parenting time for mom were noted as a few were missed with the
last worker, Staff 1.
Interviews:
I interviewed the Foster Care Supervisor 1 by telephone on
4/17/2024. Foster Care Supervisor 1 stated documentation of the
foster home visits were in the information system for review.
Foster Care Supervisor 1 stated she reviews case information with
the workers on at least a weekly basis and would be aware if a
worker had not completed the required monthly foster home visits.
4

Foster Care Supervisor 1 stated she completed the December
2023 foster home visit with the new case manager as a
supervision and training opportunity for the new foster care
worker.
Staff 1 was the foster care worker during the time associated with
this investigation. Staff 1 left employment with this agency in
November 2023 and was not available to be contacted. Foster
Care Supervisor 1 was the supervisor of Staff 1 during that time.
I interviewed Foster Mom 1 by telephone on 4/24/2024. Foster
Mom 1 stated things were currently progressing and at a court
hearing on 4/24/2024 the parents were granted unsupervised
visitation. Foster Mom 1 stated she thought things improved when
a new case worker was assigned in December 2023. Foster Mom
1 did not confirm the completion of foster home visits and
previously had denied foster home visits occurred October-
December 2023.
I interviewed Staff 1 by telephone on 5/1/2024. Staff 1 confirmed
she had completed foster home visits for October and November.
Staff 1 reported some of the visits were completed/combined
when she picked up Youth A for parenting time.
Analysis The findings of this investigation determined the required foster
home visits were completed by the foster care worker at least
monthly as noted/documented in the social work contact record.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Medical and dental care policy
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12413
Section (1) An agency's medical and dental care policy must,
Description include all the following:
(a) The provision of routine medical care.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Foster Care Worker 1 was told by the foster parents that they
needed help getting Youth A into the doctor and dentist per our
work schedule and we were not offered help.
Investigation Documents Reviewed:
5

I reviewed the medical records for Youth A. Youth A is in
compliance with licensing rules for medicals and dentals. Youth A
has a current physical dated 11/21/2023 and a current dental
dated 1/16/2024. Both medical/dental services were completed
within the time frame required by licensing rules.
Analysis The findings of this investigation determined Youth A does have
current physical and dental examinations that were completed
within the time frame required for compliance with licensing rules.
The licensing rules for Child Placing Agencies do not dictate that
the agency needs to provide transportation to these appointments
just that they are completed.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Development of service plans
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12418
Section (5) An agency shall involve the child's parent or parents
Description and the foster parents in the development of service plans
to enable the parent or parents and foster parents to
understand the plan for the child and the parents' and the
foster parent's role in assisting the agency in carrying out
the plan. An agency shall give a copy to and review the
parent-agency treatment plan with the parent or parents
and foster parents. The agency must inform the parent or
parents and foster parent that the information in the parent-
agency treatment plan and any other information about the
child and the child's family is confidential.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Foster parents were not involved in service plan development and
implementation.
Investigation Interviews:
I attempted to interview Complainant 1 (Foster Mom 1) by
telephone on 2/1/2024 for any additional information beyond what
Complainant 1 reported during the initial complaint information.
Complainant 1 did not subsequently report any additional
information regarding the allegations.
I interviewed Administrator 1 by telephone on 2/5/2024 and
3/27/2024. Administrator 1 stated/confirmed Parent/Agency
6

Agreements involving foster parents/caregivers were not
completed for these time periods or they could not be located as
required.
I interviewed Foster Mom 1 by telephone on 4/24/2024. Foster
Mom 1 reported communication improved when a new case
manager was assigned in December 2023. Foster Mom 1 did not
confirm that she was involved in the development of service plans
with the previous foster care worker.
Documents Reviewed:
A review of the placement record for Youth A did not include
documentation that a Parent/Agency Agreement was completed
and signed involving the participation of the foster
parent/caregiver of Youth A. The record indicated Parent/Agency
Agreements were completed for the parents of Youth A dated
10/27/2023 and 1/16/2024, but no Parent/Agency Agreements
were located involving the foster parents/caregivers for these time
periods.
Analysis The findings of this investigation determined the agency did not
adequately involve the foster parents/caregivers in the
development of service plans and expectations. The development
of Parent/Agency Agreements signed by the foster
parents/caregivers provide the evidence of their involvement. In
this investigation this documentation was not able to be
provided/confirmed. Foster Mom 1 also did not report being
involved when she was interviewed.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
